Graphic abstract The fire suppression mechanisms of LIBs extinguishants and surfactants were compared based on patents. The analysis suggests that temperature-sensitive hydrogels will be the future key focus for the development of LIBs extinguishing agents. While newer, more efficient Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and extinguishing agents have been developed to reduce the occurrence of thermal runaway accidents, there is still a scarcity of research focused on the application of surfactants in different LIBs extinguishing agents, particularly in terms of patented technologies. The aim of this review paper is to provide an overview of the technological progress of LIBs and LIBs extinguishing agents in terms of patents in Korea, Japan, Europe, the United States, China, etc. The initial part of this review paper is sort out LIBs technology development in different regions. In addition, to compare LIBs extinguishing agent progress and challenges of liquid, solid, combination of multiple, and microencapsulated. The subsequent sectionof this review focuses on an in-depth analysis dedicated to the efficiency and challenges faced by the surfactants corresponding design principles of LIBs extinguishing agents, such as nonionic and anionic surfactants. A total of 451,760 LIBs-related patent and 20 LIBs-fire-extinguishing agent-related patent were included in the analyses. The extinguishing effect, cooling performance, and anti-recombustion on different agents have been highlighted. After a comprehensive comparison of these agents, this review suggests that temperature-sensitive hydrogel extinguishing agent is ideal for the effective control of LIBs fire. The progress and challenges of surfactants have been extensively examined, focusing on key factors such as surface activity, thermal stability, foaming properties, environmental friendliness, and electrical conductivity. Moreover, it is crucial to emphasize that the selection of a suitable surfactant must align with the extinguishing strategy of the extinguishing agent for optimal firefighting effectiveness. Keywords LIBs Fire-extinguishing agent Surfactants Patent 1 Introduction LIBs are electrochemical energy storage devices that can convert chemical energy into electrical energy and vice versa [1,2]. From the perspective of storing energy per unit mass or volume, the energy density of LIBs is second only to nuclear energy, making them an important energy storage medium in today’s society [3]. Table 1 presents the performance parameters of current LIBs in three major application fields: 3C devices, power batteries, and energy storage batteries. In the process of continuous pursuit of increased capacity and power in LIBs, the accompanying safety issues have become a significant barrier to technological development [5]. For a LIBs cell, when it is subjected to conditions outside its rated operating range, a series of complex reactions including electrochemical reactions, phase changes, mixing effects, and Joule heating occur within the battery. This leads to rapid self-heating of LIBs [6]. According to the Semyonov thermal runaway theory [7] (Fig. 1 ), when the heat generated by an exothermic reaction is not offset by the loss of heat to the environment, heat accumulation occurs in the battery cell, leading to an increase in temperature and an accelerated reaction, thus resulting in thermal runaway [8–11]. For a Li-ion battery module consisting of multiple cells, according to Fourier's law of heat conduction [12] (Fig. 2 ), when one of the cells undergoes TR, the heat generated by it warms up the other adjacent cells continuously using heat conduction [13], thus extending the TR range continuously [14]. (1) Q cond,tabs = k tab A c ( T 1 - T 2 ) ω Among them, Q cond,tabs is the heat flux, k tab is the thermal conductivity, A c is the heat transfer area, and ( T 1 - T 2 ) ω is the temperature gradient. The larger the battery module, the greater the risk of fire and explosion and the greater the difficulty of extinguishing it. Although the TR process of LIBs follows classical aerodynamic laws in terms of heat transfer, the complex chemical reactions within them make the whole TR process sufficiently special (Figs. 3 and 4 ). To solve the problem of TR during the application of LIBs, many scholars have started to study the safety of LIBs [17–19]. The TR problem of LIBs is mainly due to three causes: thermal abuse, electrical abuse, and mechanical abuse [8], which lead to internal short circuits due to the rupture of the internal diaphragm of the battery [20–22]. However, a TR in LIBs is not simply a short circuit within the battery, but a chemical crosstalk between the cathode and the anode during battery operation. This crosstalk causes the oxygen released from the cathode to cross the diaphragm and react with the Li x C of the anode, generating a large amount of heat and thus triggering TR [23]. According to the thermal runaway principle of lithium-ion batteries, many scholars have sought to enhance the stability of internal cathode, anode, and electrolyte materials in LIBs [24–26]. The development of flame retardants capable of effectively enhancing the safety of battery electrolytes, and their incorporation as electrolyte additives within batteries, as well as the investigation of fire-resistant gel polymer electrolytes [27], the regulation of solid-state electrolyte interfaces and solvent structures [28], are currently significant research directions. Wu and his team have developed a novel flame-retardant oligomer, PPO, and incorporated it as a flame retardant into the electrolyte material of batteries to enhance their safety performance [9]. Wang et al. developed a novel flame-retardant and stable gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) by chemically bonding it with a flame retardant [29]. Long et al. designed an intrinsically heat-resistant and fire-resistant nano-calcium carbonate-based composite membrane (CPVH) to enhance the long-term thermal stability of batteries [30]. However, the above-mentioned methods will to some extent reduce the energy density of lithium-ion batteries [31], increase the difficulty of battery production, and raise production costs, thus affecting the commercialization process of batteries from another perspective. The TR problem of LIBs is a complex safety problem from a mechanistic analysis of physics, chemistry, electromagnetism, and other disciplines overlapping together [32]. However, considering the energy perspective, it is crucial to promptly and sufficiently dissipate the energy produced by thermal runaway (TR). This prevents the additional buildup of energy stemming from TR, guarantees the thermal stability of the lithium battery system, and maintains the thermal runaway issue of the battery under manageable control. It seems that the problem is much simpler, so some scholars have developed more targeted fire-extinguishing media for the thermodynamic characteristics of the TR phenomenon of LIBs [15,33,34], and the current more widely used is the perfluoro caprolactone gas fire extinguishing system [35]. In conclusion, as mentioned above, it is an important direction for future LIBs safety management to quickly and effectively control LIBs fires and prevent further propagation of thermal runaway effects within the battery module, through the heat absorption and cooling effects of fire suppression agents, without compromising the energy efficiency of the battery. The selection of surfactants as key components in the formulation of fire extinguishing agents has a significant impact on the fire suppression effectiveness. This article aims to analyze and study practical issues such as the selection and application of surfactants in LIBs fire extinguishing agents, starting from patents. It provides new directions for the design and development of fire suppression media for future LIBs. 2 LIBs patents analysis 2.1 Regional analysis of patents A total of 451,760 LIBs-related patents were searched within the US, China, Japan, Europe, and Korea, of which 51.77% and 28.04% were invention patents and utility model patents respectively, with 64,499 openings. The content of LIBs-related patents has been increasing year by year since 1998, and the upward trend peaked in 2020 before showing a downward trend (Fig. 5 ). A hybrid vehicle control device was earlier proposed by Denso Corp of Japan in their patent for a Hybrid vehicle control device (No. JP2015120482A [36]) back in 1983, which can properly preheat the catalyst when catalyst preheating requirements and SOC control requirements arise to avoid reducing fuel economy while ensuring battery rechargeability. This is an earlier technology for improving the efficiency of the conversion of fuel and electricity in hybrid vehicles, and the battery mentioned in the patent is a rechargeable LIBs. It can be seen that by this time Japan already had more mature technology related to LIBs and had already started to promote the use of LIBs in the automotive engine sector. In 1985, China carried out the use of solid electrolyte lithium montmorillonite as the solid electrolyte and cathode active material in batteries to make lithium solid electrolyte batteries with high specific energy (No. CN85103963A [37]). At this time, China had not yet set foot in the research field of LIBs and was still at the stage of lithium metal batteries such as solid LIBs, lithium iodine batteries, and lithium alloy batteries [38–40]. Patent “Process for assembling the thin film components of an electrochemical generator with lithium electrode” (No. EP0298801A1 [41]), was filed in France in 1988. The patent invents a lithium thin film battery with a composite positive electrode consisting of lithium or lithium alloy as the negative electrode material, a solid polymer for lithium-ion conduction as the electrolyte, vanadium oxide (40% by volume) as the positive electrode, a black solution of acetic acid (10% by volume) and polyoxyethylene, and details the specific manufacturing process. The mechanical strength of all the materials that make up the cell allows the inventive cell to be driven, transferred, bonded and finally assembled at high speed in a variety of devices, representing an important breakthrough in the industrial mass production of LIBs. In 1989, the Japanese company Toray Silicone Co., Ltd. filed a patent in the United States for “Ionically conductive material and method for its preparation” (Patent No. US5194180 [42]), which was a patent for cross-linking metal ions into copolymers to produce a safer solid electrolyte with good conductivity for use in electronic devices such as batteries and displays, in which lithium perchlorate (LiClO4), lithium fluoroborate (LiBF4), lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6), lithium trifluoro methanesulphonate (LiCF3SO3), lithium iodide (LiI) were preferred as metal salts to provide metal ions, starting the historical process of continuous optimization of the energy density of LIBs. In 1993, Electronics and Telecommunications Research Institute (South Korea) applied for the patent “A positive electrode material of a lithium secondary battery and a method of manufacturing the same” (No. KR950021838A [43]) in Korea. The patent invented a lithium-ion secondary battery with Li X Na1− X CO y Ni1− y O2 as the cathode active material, the pillar was raised to get into the small ions such as Li between the MO layer using a Na, provided an important research base for the development of ternary LIBs. In 2002, Li et al. applied for a patent in Taiwan, China, for a method of regenerating waste lithium battery resources (No. TW200408155A [44]). Although the application date was later than in other regions, the patent content is of high value and achieves the purpose of reusing waste resources by recovering nickel, cobalt, and lithium metals. By analyzing the earliest patent applications related to LIBs in different regions, it can be found that Japan’s patent research and development in LIBs was the earliest and of high quality, and other countries besides China have also quickly embarked on the right track in the patent research and development of LIBs, all of which have achieved breakthroughs in different directions such as material optimization, production process optimization and energy density optimization in the field of LIBs. Although there is a sequence in the timing of the first application for LIBs-related patents, they are still able to build on each other and develop together in a blossoming manner, except in China where there is a disconnect between the application for LIBs-related patents and other regions and the phenomenon of closed doors. Fig. 6 reveals that patents in all regions are mainly retained in their regions in priority, with China retaining as much as 97.24% of its patents locally, and 27.48% and 25.01% of the LIBs patents in Japan and Korea flowing to the US in priority. The US was the preferred region for patent flow by region, with Europe second only to the US in popularity, with more intra-European patent exchanges and few patent exchanges between China and other regions. 2.2 Analysis of patent applicants The top ten standard applicants in the number of patent applications related to LIBs are mainly companies from Japan and Korea, with a total of 55,846 patent applications, accounting for 12.33% of the total number of patents, as shown in the figure (Figs. 7 and 8 ). Toyota has an obvious advantage in terms of the number of patent applications, but the degree of patent characteristics is low. Samsung and Panasonic have better overall quality of patents, with higher levels of patent degree and characteristics. CATL and State Grid from China also perform well. The US and European regions lack large-scale local leading units in the field of independent patent applications for LIBs, relying mainly on the inflow of patents from Japan and Korea. In terms of patent applications, the key standard applicants mainly focus on innovative research on internal battery materials, new battery types, battery energy density, and battery application management (Fig. 9 ), with little research on battery safety. 3 Patent analysis of LIBs extinguishing agents As LIBs TR fires are characterized by rapid heating and high temperatures, heat transfer and heat build-up can easily occur between battery units, resulting in a large-scale fire, the release of flammable and explosive gases can cause an explosion [21,45] (Fig. 10 ). In LIBs accidents, leaks or fires can lead to the release of highly reactive, toxic species such as phosphorus trifluoride (POF3) or hydrofluoric acid (HF). This is because the electrolyte salt lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) is used in almost all lithium-ion systems or lithium-ion polymer systems. When the battery safety valve is opened, the substance flows out, generating phosphorus trifluoride (POF3), phosphoric acid (H3PO4) as well as hydrofluoric acid (HF), thus posing a great danger to humans and the environment. Compared to conventional extinguishing agents, LIBs extinguishing media need to have a greater rapid cooling capacity, continuous cooling capacity, and gas adsorption capacity while maintaining low electrical conductivity. Carbon dioxide, ABC dry powder, and 3% aqueous film-forming foam extinguishing agents were all effective in extinguishing the open flame of 18,650 lithium cobalt-acid battery fires, but re-ignition occurred after extinguishing the fire, and the time of re-ignition was proportional to the cooling capacity of the extinguishing agent [45]. Fine water mist extinguishing agents have obvious advantages over ultra-fine dry powder extinguishing agents [46]. Water can successfully extinguish lithium battery fires in electric vehicles, but there are shortcomings such as high water consumption and long extinguishing times. Additives such as F-500 and Fire sorb can effectively improve the efficiency of lithium battery fires, reducing the extinguishing time from tens of seconds to a few seconds and greatly reducing water consumption [47]. After adding a certain proportion of surfactant to pure water, the extinguishing time is greatly reduced. However, the addition of no more than 5% surfactant can significantly inhibit lithium battery fires, and when the addition ratio exceeds 5%, the time to extinguish lithium battery fires tends to be smooth and does not continue to decline, and the amount of surfactant used tends to be saturated [48]. The control simulation model of the high-pressure fine water mist fire extinguishing system was established by Anylogic and FDS, and it was found that the efficiency of high-pressure fine water mist fire extinguishing is positively related to the pressure [49]. The average temperature rise rate of the battery during the rapid warming phase was taken as the rate of warming between the time the release of the extinguishing agent ceased and the time the surface temperature of the battery reached its peak temperature, and it was found that the cooling effect was in the order of water > PFC > HFC > ABC dry powder > CO2 [50] (Fig. 11 ). CO2, foam extinguishing agent, fine water mist, water, dry powder extinguishing agent on LIBs fire suppression study found that water and foam extinguishing agent in the cooling phase is the most outstanding performance, although the rapid warming phenomenon of water is more prominent, temperature fluctuations are more obvious, but the overall temperature control effect performance is the best [33] (Fig. 12 ). During the TR of a Li-ion battery module, heat transfer from the battery housing is the main heat transfer channel for the thermal spread of the battery pack. Flames have little effect on TR propagation but may cause serious damage to accessories above the battery module (Fig. 13 ). Therefore, more attention should be paid to finding ways to prevent TR propagation through the battery casing [13]. Special attention needs to be paid to the fact that the wrong use of extinguishing agents can further increase the size of a TR fire in LIBs. In the battery TR extinguishing experiments with heptafluoropropane, carbon dioxide, and ultra-fine dry powder, it was found that the ultra-fine dry powder extinguishing agent was not only unable to effectively suppress the TR phenomenon of the battery, but also caused an explosion [51]. Perfluorocaprolactone is subject to fire enhancement and significant HF production during high-temperature fire suppression [52]. In summary, the existing traditional fire extinguishing agents cannot solve the problem of TR of LIBs or even further escalate the danger, therefore, the development of high-efficiency LIBs-specific fire extinguishing agents is very urgent and necessary. Patents related to LIBs fire extinguishers first appeared in Japan in 2007, nine years later than other patents related to LIBs. 140 related patents were searched within China, the United States, Japan, Korea, and Europe, of which 60.00% were invention patents and 9.29% were utility models (Fig. 14 ). The US [53], Korea [54], Europe [55], and China [56] began to focus on the passive safety of LIBs in 2008, 2012, 2013, and 2014, respectively, and the first proposed patents related to LIBs fire extinguishing, but the contents were all about the use of traditional fire extinguishing agents to develop a new type of TR anti-fire extinguishing device for LIBs. In 2007, the Japanese company Sharp first proposed a safer battery pack in the patent “Battery pack” (No. JP2009099322A [57]) by adding an outer layer of packaging material containing a fire extinguishing agent to the outside of the battery. Among the extinguishing agents, protein foam, fluoro protein foam, surfactant foam, sodium bicarbonate, potassium bicarbonate, sodium phosphate, sodium bicarbonate, aluminum sulfate, ammonium sulfate, ammonium dihydrogen phosphate, etc. are particularly preferred. In 2009, the Japanese company Mitsubishi Motors proposed a battery safety device that uses a water-based extinguishing agent to submerge a TR automotive power battery in time in the patent “Extinction structure of electric vehicle” (No. JP2013136266A [58]). In 2012, Hochiki Corp, the first Japanese manufacturer of disaster prevention products, applied for a patent “Power storage device” (No. JP2014082108A [59]) for a fire extinguishing system in which a smoke detection device installed in the housing container of a battery module for incident detection and an aerosol extinguishing agent is used to intervene promptly against TR of the battery, thereby suppressing explosive combustion of LIBs housed in a power storage device caused by a building fire. Most patents related to LIBs fire extinguishing are different fire extinguishing devices developed using existing extinguishing agents for different LIBs application scenarios, of which only 20 patents are for the development of special extinguishing agents for LIBs TR accidents in response to the TR characteristics of LIBs. The US has the earliest application and China has the largest number of applications (Fig. 15 ). Among numerous fire extinguishing agents, deionized water and perfluorohexane are the most widely used. Deionized water, known for its high latent heat of vaporization, low cost, and non-conductive properties, quickly removes a large amount of heat through its substantial evaporation heat, thus achieving rapid fire suppression and cooling. Perfluorohexane possesses characteristics of high density, high specific heat, non-conductivity, non-corrosiveness, and no residue. It not only achieves rapid cooling through vaporization and heat absorption, but also employs high-temperature decomposition to capture active free radicals generated during combustion, thereby disrupting chain reactions and achieving chemical inhibition. According to the different forms of extinguishing agents, this study classifies them into four sections for presentation and analysis: liquid extinguishing agents, solid extinguishing agents, combined use of multiple extinguishing agents and microencapsulated extinguishing agents. Liquid fire extinguishing agent invention patents can be applied to sprinkler fire extinguishing control systems, with a wide range of applications and outstanding fire extinguishing and cooling effects, which is the main direction for the development of fire extinguishing agents. The patents for gaseous fire extinguishing agent inventions are mainly for perfluorohexanone composite fire extinguishing agents. By overcoming the shortcomings of high requirements for the use of scenarios due to the gaseous nature of perfluorohexanone, the patents make use of the addition of different surfactants to enhance the adaptability of perfluorohexanone scenarios and further improve the fire-extinguishing performance of perfluorohexanone. The patent for the invention of a solid fire extinguishing agent mainly optimizes the granularity of dry powder extinguishing agents and aerosol extinguishing agents. Microcapsule type fire extinguishing agent invention patent is for LIBs TR specific temperature change characteristics, gas release law, making shell material, wrapping specified fire extinguishing media, multi-angle control of LIBs fire, but storage stability needs to be strengthened, the production process is too complex (Fig. 16 ). 3.1 Liquid fire extinguishing agents Liquid extinguishing agents include aqueous extinguishing agents, water colloid extinguishing agents, foam extinguishing agents, etc. Water has a strong ability to absorb heat, the burning material has a significant cooling effect, water vaporization produces a large amount of water vapor, crowding out and preventing air from entering the combustion area, which can reduce the content of oxygen in the combustion area (Fig. 17 ). In addition, water is cheap and easy to obtain, has a wide range of sources, and the pollution of the environment is small. But water also has obvious shortcomings, water due to good mobility, most of the water sprayed into the fire will be lost, or because of the high temperature of the fire water has not reached the combustion zone and has vaporized, so the cooling performance of water cannot give full play. Different research scholars through the water surfactant compounding, water-soluble polymer gel structure of water absorption and expansion, foam agent aqueous solution and air miscibility, and other different methods invented aqueous fire extinguishing agents, water colloid fire extinguishing agents, and foam extinguishing agents. 3.1.1 Water-based fire extinguishing agents Water-based fire extinguishing agents by adding reagents to water, change the physical properties of water, increase the latent heat of vaporization, viscosity, wetting power, and adhesion, improve the effective oxygen barrier and cooling capacity of water, extend the residence time of water in the burning area, reduce the flow resistance of water, increase the cooling and protection area of water, give full play to the fire extinguishing properties of water, reduce the dosage and improve the efficiency of fire extinguishing. In 2019, Xiamen Yitai Fire Technology Development Co., Ltd. in China invented a water-based fire extinguishing agent composed of 10%–20% C6F12O, 15%–35% fluorocarbon surfactants, 10%–15% ethylene glycol, 1%–3% ethanol, 0.5%–3% polyacrylic acid, and the remaining water. This fire extinguishing agent utilizes the heat-absorbing vaporization of C6F12O and water to reduce the temperature at the ignition site and lower the re-ignition probability of LIBs fire. (No. CN110368631A [60]). In 2020, Nanjing University of Technology in China developed a non-conductive ultrafine water mist fire extinguishing agent. This fire extinguishing agent is composed of non-ionic fluorine surfactant, fatty alcohol polyoxyethylene ether, urea, dimethyl methylphosphonate, and deionized water. By employing a combination of two types of additives, namely physical additives and chemical additives, and introducing a LIBs-specific flame retardant, dimethyl methylphosphonate, a better fire suppression and flame retardant effect can be achieved. (No. CN111840879A [61]). The flame extinguishing time using additives is 2 s, which is 9 s shorter than when using pure water mist. The total cooling time is reduced by 130 s, and the time required to lower the highest temperature to 100 °C is shortened by 133 s. The extinguishing speed, cooling speed, and highest temperature cooling speed are 5.5 times, 2 times, and 2.7 times faster, respectively, compared to pure fine water mist [62]. In 2020, Motifang Technology (Beijing) Co., Ltd. in China invented a water-based fire extinguishing agent for LIBs composed of ethyl acetate, perfluorohexylsulfonyl fluoride, N,N-diethyl-1,3-propanediamine, sodium hypochlorite, dibutyltin dilaurate, deionized water, sodium octylsulfonate, potassium perfluorobutanesulfonate, and diethylene glycol monobutyl ether. This extinguishing agent achieves efficient fire suppression through the principle of oxygen isolation using perfluorohexyl polysaccharide copolymers. (No. CN111840878A [63]). In 2022, Beijing Institute of Technology in China invented two water-based fire extinguishing agents specifically designed for LIBs with low conductivity (No. CN115400384A [64]) and high cooling properties (No. CN115671640A [65]). These agents were developed by combining organic silicone surfactants, fluorine surfactants, and hydrocarbon surfactants, along with various types and proportions of polyols and esters. The resulting formulations demonstrated remarkable performance in terms of insulation and cooling capabilities. In the experiment of extinguishing thermal runaway in 3 sets of 18,650 batteries, compared to pure fine water mist and 3% F-500, both of the above-mentioned fire extinguishing agents effectively suppressed thermal propagation, with only one battery experiencing thermal runaway. In contrast, pure fine water mist and 3% F-500 saw multiple batteries undergo thermal runaway. The advantage of water-based fire extinguishers lies in their excellent cooling performance. However, the insulation properties cannot be guaranteed. Although some patents ensure the insulation of water-based fire extinguishers themselves through methods such as deionized water and fine water mist injection, the substances released during thermal runaway of batteries mixed with the insulated water-based fire extinguishers will still cause the extinguishing agent to lose its insulation properties, thereby increasing the hazard at the accident scene. Therefore, the research focus on water-based fire extinguishers is not only on the insulation performance before the discharge of the reagent but also on the insulation performance after the reagent is mixed with substances such as electrolytes released by the battery. 3.1.2 Hydrocolloid fire extinguishing agents All water-soluble or hydrophilic polymers can form hydrogels through certain chemical cross-linking or physical cross-linking. These macromolecules can be divided into two main categories according to their origin: natural and synthetic. Natural hydrophilic polymers include polysaccharides (starch, cellulose, alginate, hyaluronic acid, chitosan, etc.) and peptides (collagen, poly-L-lysine, poly-L-glutamic acid, etc.). Synthetic hydrophilic polymers include alcohols, acrylic acid, and its derivatives (polyacrylic acid, polymethacrylic acid, polyacrylamide, poly-N-polyacrylamide, etc.). The three-dimensional network structure of hydrogels is extremely hydrophilic and can swell rapidly in water and can retain a large volume of water without dissolving. In 2010, SB LiMotive Company, Ltd. of the United States first invented a gel-type fire extinguisher with suspending properties, specifically designed to suppress LIBs fires. The gel consists of a suspension solution comprising water, salts with calcium, magnesium, or strontium cations that are poorly soluble in water, and a water thickening agent (No. US20130207018A1 [66]). Among them, the dilute solution of alkaline earth metal cations can react with substances such as phosphorus trifluoride, phosphoric acid, and hydrogen fluoride, producing insoluble fluorides that are not soluble in water. The thickening agent is employed to disperse metal salts more effectively in water, and its concentration can be adjusted according to user requirements. As a safety precaution, the protective layer of the fire extinguishing agent arranged in the container can possess relatively high viscosity, while the fire extinguishing agent to be sprayed can have lower viscosity to ensure good sprayability. Subsequently, Samsung SDI and Robert Bosch GmbH jointly developed a similar concept in 2012, a gel-based lithium battery specialized fire extinguishing and flame-retardant agent, which utilizes the combined effects of alkaline earth metal carboxylates and swellable polymers (No. US20140034864A1, Fig. 18 [67]). Compared to other acid salts of alkaline earth metals, alkaline earth metal carboxylates possess a higher average oxidation state of carbon, enabling them to provide a small amount of energy and generate a significant amount of carbon dioxide during the combustion process. Alkaline earth metal carboxylates, especially calcium carboxylate, can be applied in the form of aqueous solutions and still retain a certain flame-retardant effect after drying. The gel fire extinguisher composed of swellable polymer, calcium lactate gluconate, gum arabic, and polyethylene glycol significantly reduces the emission of smoke generated by thermal runaway of batteries during fire suppression. There is no fluoride and phosphate ions were detected in the extinguishing water. In 2021, Xuzhou Klingsmann Security Technology Co., Ltd. of China invented a LIBs fire extinguishing agent with a dissolving solution consisting of polyoxyethylene fatty acid esters, glycerol stearate, and polyoxyethylene aryl ether components and a dissolving agent consisting of water, vermiculite particles, acrylic acid, methylene bisacrylamide, and polyvinylpyrrolidone components (No. CN114192040A [68]). The gel swelling property of aqueous colloidal fire suppressants enables the persistent adsorption of water on the surface of batteries, thereby achieving continuous cooling. This serves as an effective means to contain the propagation of thermal runaway in LIBs. Experimental evidence from the implementation of the US patent 2014.0034.864A1 clearly confirms the significant impact of gel-based fire suppressants’ swelling property on cooling and temperature reduction. It also serves as a crucial criterion for future research on gel-based fire suppressants specifically designed for lithium-ion applications. 3.1.3 Foam fire extinguishing agents Foam extinguishing agents emerged in the late 18th century and were originally used in Class B fires. They are agents in which an aqueous solution of foam is mixed with air or carbon dioxide to produce foam for extinguishing fires by chemical reaction or mechanical means. Because foam is lighter than the aqueous solution from which it is derived and lighter than combustible liquids, it can be suspended on the surface of the liquid. The suspended foam forms a water-based air barrier that inhibits and stops combustion by preventing the evaporation of the fuel. For Class A fires, foam extinguishing agents spread quickly, adhere to combustible materials, and are far more capable of extinguishing fires than water. In 2022, Beijing University of Technology invented a perfluorocaprostone foam fire extinguishing agent (No. CN115192952A56, Fig. 19 [69]) by compounding a perfluorocaprostone gas fire extinguishing agent with a fluorosurfactant and a co-surfactant, the rapid cooling and cooling of LIBs by water promotes the inhibiting effect of the perfluorocaprostone component on the chain reaction of TR inside the battery, while the perfluorocaprostone. The enhanced inhibitory effect of the chain reaction of the perfluorohexanone component reduces the smoke concentration and thermal buoyancy, making it easier for the water mist particles to reach the surface of the battery, which can fully stimulate the interaction between perfluorohexanone and water and significantly enhance the fire extinguishing and anti-combustion effects of the extinguishing agent. In terms of rapid cooling, this mixed formula reduces the peak temperature on the battery surface by 82.03 °C, achieving an improvement of 156% and 28% in cooling efficiency compared to perfluorohexane and water, respectively. As for sustained cooling, after the release of the extinguishing agent, the battery temperature rose by 163.63 °C. In comparison to perfluorohexane and water, it exhibited an enhanced suppression efficiency of 18.5% and 24%, respectively. 3.1.4 Other liquid fire extinguishing agents In 2015, The Chemers Company F.C. of Japan invented a combination of a liquid fluoropolyether and a flame retardant capable of inhibiting the combustion of LIBs by forming carbides during combustion (No. JP2017528866A [70]). The invention concentrates the originally liquid composition into a semi-solid state, and when the temperature rises, the combustion inhibitor releases water, nitrogen, nitrogen dioxide, carbon dioxide or sulfur dioxide while the composition absorbs heat, expands, and forms carbides, keeping the TR of the battery within the range of a damaged cell. 3.1.5 Summary Different reactions in various stages of LIBs thermal runaway release a significant amount of heat. The accumulation of heat further fuels the occurrence of thermal runaway reactions, making temperature control and reduction a necessary condition to prevent the spread of lithium battery thermal runaway. Water-based fire suppressants exhibit excellent cooling effects, which become more pronounced with increasing dosage [65]. Water-based extinguishing agents are the main direction of current patent inventions due to their adaptability to sprinkler systems and low level of modification to fire extinguishing devices. The hydrolysis of lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6), an important electrolyte in LIBs, with moisture in the air, forming hydrogen fluoride (HF) and phosphorus trifluoride (POF3) [71] makes the application of water-based extinguishing agents and foam extinguishing agents in LIBs TR incidents constrained. Although colloidal fire extinguishers can continuously lower temperatures and release insoluble salts through the reaction between alkaline earth metal salts and fluoride and phosphate ions during thermal runaway, the swelling performance of the gel substance needs to be emphasized. It is also necessary to possess advantages in utilizing the latent heat of water evaporation for rapid fire suppression and cooling. Therefore, the combination and application of water-based fire extinguishers and water-gel fire extinguishers is more ideal (Fig. 20 ). Water-based fire extinguishers provide a large amount of latent heat of vaporization to instantly extinguish open flames, while the continuous cooling ability of water-gel extinguishers is utilized to promptly cool down the batteries, control the spread of thermal runaway, and simultaneously convert toxic and harmful gases into sediment for absorption. While the water colloid fire extinguishing agent can be solidified through chemical reactions during continuous cooling to address the absorption of toxic gases, its effectiveness in fire suppression is weakened due to the colloid's significant water absorption. Insufficient latent heat of vaporization is provided, necessitating reliance on continuous cooling to manage thermal runaway in damaged batteries. This, to a certain extent, escalates the challenge of controlling battery thermal runaway incidents. Therefore, the combination of aqueous extinguishing agents and hydrocolloid extinguishing agents is ideal, using aqueous extinguishing agents to provide a large amount of latent heat of vaporization to extinguish the open fire immediately, and then using the continuous cooling capacity of the hydrocolloid to cool the battery in time, while the toxic and harmful gases into precipitates to absorb, for LIBs TR accident are very ideal. 3.2 Solid fire extinguishing agents Fire extinguishing agents in the form of solid powder are collectively referred to as solid extinguishing agents, generally referred mainly to dry powder extinguishing agents, as aerosol extinguishing agents contain ultra-fine solid powder, so it is usually also classified in the category of solid extinguishing agents (Fig. 21 ). 3.2.1 Dry powder fire extinguishing agents The dry powder extinguishing agent is composed of one or more kinds of fine inorganic powder with a fire extinguishing function and filler and additives with specific functions. Compared with other extinguishing agents, dry powder extinguishing agent has the characteristics of a fast fire extinguishing rate, simple production process, wide temperature range, no special requirements for the environment, no external power and water source, non-toxic, non-pollution, and safety. When the dry powder extinguishing agent is added to the combustion area and mixed with the flame, the dry powder comes into contact with the free radicals in the flame, the free radicals are adsorbed on the powder surface and undergo the following transformation reactions. (1) M ( Powders ) + · OH → MOH MOH + H · → M + H 2 O Through the above reaction, the ·H and ·OH radicals in the combustion reaction are consumed with the help of the powder. However, when a large amount of powder is sprayed into the flame in the form of a mist, the free radicals in the flame are adsorbed and converted in large quantities, causing a sharp reduction in the number of free radicals, resulting in the interruption of the chain reaction of combustion and ultimately the extinction of the flame. In 2017, Flood and Gerald of the United States invented a lighter dry powder extinguishing agent for LIBs with stronger flow properties consisting of 85%–98.5% dry powder extinguishing agent, 0.5%–10% glass spheres of 10–170 microns in diameter and 1%–5% ceramic spheres of 20–60 microns in diameter, thus overcoming the disadvantages of traditional dry powder extinguishing agents in terms of high pressure spraying leading to flame (Fig. 22 ). The disadvantages of high-pressure spraying of traditional dry powder extinguishing agents, such as flame spread and large particles, affect the efficiency of fire extinguishing (No. US20180250541A1 [72]). In 2022, the South China University of Technology invented a hydrated inorganic salt dry powder fire extinguishing agent. Among them, the decomposition temperature of the hydrated inorganic salt component of the hydrated inorganic salt dry powder fire extinguishing agent is low, which better matches the initial temperature range where TR of LIBs occurs, and has a strong heat absorption capacity, and the decomposition process can produce a large amount of gas to dilute the oxygen concentration, so that it can effectively reduce the temperature of the object and the oxygen concentration in the environment, and has an effective inhibiting effect on the TR of LIBs (No: CN114887272A [73]). The research on the invention patent of dry powder fire extinguishing agent lacks comparative studies on the fire extinguishing effects between different fire extinguishing agents and different types of dry powder fire extinguishing agents. Dry powder fire extinguishers are less effective than water in suppressing thermal runaway incidents in LIBs (Fig. 23 ) [34]. However, due to its convenient storage and easy usability, it is therefore more suitable for the prevention and early intervention of thermal runaway incidents in small-scale LIBs. 3.2.2 Aerosol-based fire extinguishing agents Aerosol fire extinguishing agent is a fire suppression medium comprising a dispersed phase of liquid or solid, and a dispersing medium of gas, forming an aerosol system with particle size smaller than 5 μm. Its distinctive characteristics lie in the minute size of solid particles, resembling the properties of a gas. This unique attribute allows it to effortlessly navigate around obstacles, reaching even the most remote corners of a fire, and lingering for an extended period. As a result, it achieves complete fire suppression through full flooding, surpassing the efficiency of traditional dry powder extinguishing agents. 2021 Yamato Protec Corp, Europe, invented a fire extinguishing tablet containing a potassium compound as a fire extinguishing agent by interrupting the combustion chain through negative catalysis of an aerosol that produces potassium radicals (a potassium compound) at high temperatures (No. EP4094810A1 [74]). This design can be directly attached to the battery packaging without manual intervention, and it acts spontaneously when encountering the phenomenon of thermal runaway in batteries, effectively preventing the spread of thermal runaway in small-capacity LIBs. Although the suppression performance of thermal runaway in large-capacity batteries remains to be verified, the design concept of automatic temperature rise response can provide more timely control of accidents and is worthy of reference. 3.2.3 Summary Solid fire extinguishing agent patents are mainly based on dry powder, although dry powder has the characteristics of high efficiency and fast fire extinguishing, dry powder extinguishing agent extinguishes the LIBs cooling effect very little, and does not have the role of coverage. Therefore, in the LIBs TR environment, due to incomplete fire extinguishing and poor cooling efficiency, etc., easy to cause re-ignition, and cannot achieve the absorption of toxic gases, wrapping role. Aerosols are much more efficient and have no directional diffusion. Regardless of the direction of the spray or the position of the nozzle, they can quickly spread to the protected space in a relatively short time and can also overcome the spatial limitations of obstacles. However, whether dry powder or aerosols, solid particles have a certain irritating effect on human breathing and can also affect visibility and rescue at the scene. 3.3 Combination of multiple fire extinguishing agents To better address the thermal runaway safety issue of LIBs, researchers have also explored the combined use of multiple fire extinguishing agents, among which perfluorohexane has been widely employed in the fire extinguishing agent combinations. Perfluorohexanone (CF3CF2COCF(CF3)2) has a short atmospheric residence time (ALT value of 5d), low greenhouse effect (GWP value of 1), does not damage the ozone layer (ODP value of 0), and low fire extinguishing concentration (4.5%–5.8%) and is a new type of highly efficient and environmentally friendly clean fire extinguishing agent [75], which has been used in the field of TR of LIBs. Combining perfluorhexanone with other materials, is one of the main research directions of many researchers to further strengthen the sustained cooling ability and chemical inhibition of the composite fire extinguishing agent while bringing into play the excellent temperature reduction ability of perfluorhexanone (Fig. 24 ). 3.3.1 Gas-liquid composite fire extinguishing agent In 2018, the Power Science Research Institute of China developed a gas–liquid composite fire extinguishing agent composed of perfluoroketone, perfluoropolyether, perfluoroalkyl ether, and perfluoropolyalkyl ether compounds (No. CN109091790A [76]). The process of vaporizing low-boiling perfluoroketones in the liquid mixture absorbs heat, reducing the temperature of the ignited battery and consequently minimizing the generation of oxygen within the battery. By utilizing perfluoropolyethers, perfluoroalkyl ethers, and perfluoroalkyl polyethers with good thermal stability and oxidation resistance, the battery is effectively isolated from the surrounding air, preventing contact between the battery and external oxygen. In comparison to conventional fire extinguishing agents with limited performance, this approach specifically addresses the unique situation of oxygen generation by LIBs at high temperatures. It addresses the generation of oxygen within the battery and the interaction between the battery and external oxygen separately, thereby enhancing the fire suppression capability. 3.3.2 Gas-solid composite fire extinguishing agents Ltd. of China invented a special fire extinguishing agent for LIBs consisting of a fluorinated organic material with a heat of vaporization not exceeding 100 kJ kg−1, a fluorinated organic material with a heat of vaporization higher than 100 kJ kg−1, and a montmorillonite loaded with activated alumina and urea as the anti-corrosion material. Through reasonable compounding, the LIBs fire extinguishing agent has a suitable boiling point, high heat of vaporization, and high specific heat, both fire extinguishing and cooling performance, while effectively and quickly extinguishing LIBs fires can prevent re-ignition, while the fire extinguishing process will not corrode electrical equipment, causing secondary damage (No. CN113350730A [77]). The suitable boiling point of fire extinguishing materials helps them to absorb heat at lower temperatures, effectively controlling fire incidents. Cooling materials with high heat of vaporization and specific heat are responsible for controlling the high temperature phenomenon after thermal runaway of LIBs, preventing heat propagation. This design approach, which divides lithium battery fire extinguishing agents into firefighting and cooling components, is highly valuable and aligns better with the practical conditions of lithium battery thermal runaway. However, the environmental and toxicological aspects of fluorinated organic compounds require special attention. Pentafluorobutane and tetrafluoropropyl ether are both mildly toxic, thus the research on fire extinguishing agents should not only focus on their firefighting and cooling effectiveness but also consider their environmental and toxicological properties. 3.3.3 Liquid-solid composite fire extinguishing agents In 2021, China Dongfang Electric Group Science and Technology Research Institute Co., Ltd. invented a high-efficiency perfluorocaproone solid and liquid two-phase composite fire extinguishing agent. The invention includes an oil-based liquid fire extinguishing agent formed by perfluorohexanone and nonionic phosphorus-containing flame retardants, halogenated flame retardants such as bromine-based types, halogenated phosphate ester mixed flame retardants, and inorganic and organic salt-based solid flame retardants or solid flame retardant co-effects. Perfluorohexanone fire extinguishing agent responds when TR occurs in LIBs, taking a submerged approach with asphyxiation and chemical inhibition, which can quickly extinguish open fires and reduce smoke concentration; the mixed flame retardant, while playing a fire extinguishing role, can act quickly with the free radicals ·H and ·OH that decompose after the battery heats up or burns, slowing down the process of the chain reaction of combustion, by decomposing small molecules in the flame. The inhibition effect is achieved. Mixed solid inorganic or organic salt flame retardants, when playing the role of fire extinguishing, mainly in the form of blistering or granules directly covering the surface of the battery, play a role in asphyxiation, isolation, and cooling (No. CN113209536A, Fig. 25 [78]). The compound fire extinguishing agent is simple to prepare, inexpensive, environmentally friendly, and has an excellent effect in suppressing LIBs fires. 3.3.4 Summary The recognition of PFC is based on the high efficiency, environmental protection, and non-toxicity of the extinguishing agent itself, but in the actual application at the fire site, in addition to further strengthening the continuous cooling and cooling capacity of PFC, the thermal decomposition characteristics of the extinguishing agent and the potential hazards of thermal decomposition products should also be fully considered, which is the key to evaluating the quality of fire protection of PFC extinguishing agents [79]. Fluorine-containing fire extinguishing agents are susceptible to deHF reaction and C–C bond-breaking reaction by heat, producing CF3, CF2, CFO, and other free radicals that can capture the consumption of free radicals in the flame and interrupt the combustion chain reaction, thermal decomposition is an important basis and way of its chemical fire extinguishing, but the HF and other substances produced by thermal decomposition have strong toxicity and corrosiveness when its concentration reaches a certain level will cause harm to the protected personnel and equipment [80], which is an important problem that cannot be solved even by compound joint fire extinguishing agents. 3.4 Microencapsulated fire extinguishing agents Microencapsulation is a technology that uses mechanical or chemical inhibition to encapsulate small solid particles, liquids, or gases in a polymeric material to make a micro-encapsulation with a particle size of 1–5000 microns that is stable under normal conditions. The outer layer of polymer material is usually referred to as the shell material and the embedded material is the core material. The diameter of microcapsules is generally between 1 micron and 1000 microns, and the thickness of the walls is generally between 0.2 microns and 1 micron. Microencapsulation is currently the most effective method for small-scale encapsulation. The most important feature of microencapsulation is that it allows for the encapsulation of materials at the micron or even nanometre scale, resulting in particles with a core-shell structure, thus greatly increasing the specific surface area of the encapsulated material. In addition, it allows for the immobilization of the encapsulated material, reducing the impact of volume changes on material properties [81]. In addition, microencapsulated fire extinguishants have the ability to effectively encapsulate and standardize various fire extinguishing agents with different physical forms, greatly simplifying the use and storage of multiple composite fire extinguishants. F-500 is a liquid microencapsulated fire extinguishant that demonstrates better performance in suppressing thermal runaway in LIBs compared to fine water mist, particularly for batteries at 60% state of charge (SOC) and 80% SOC (Figs. 26 and 27 ) [82]. In 2019, Jiaxing College in China developed a microencapsulated fire extinguishing agent consisting of a thermoresponsive polymer shell encapsulating flame retardant materials (Fig. 28 ). The thermoresponsive polymer itself is capable of sensing environmental temperature and generating effective responsive behaviors. At the lower critical solution temperature (LCST), its conformation undergoes extension or collapse changes. Taking an oxidizer in the electrolyte as an example, the ground state oxygen molecules absorb heat and transition into highly reactive singlet oxygen molecules, becoming combustion radicals. By modulating the lower critical solution temperature (LCST) of thermo-responsive polymers, the LCST is set to approximate the upper temperature limit of the LIBs safety window. When the electrolyte temperature exceeds the LCST, the thermo-responsive polymer undergoes a collapse-to-stretch transition, releasing core extinguishing materials. The flame retardant agent swiftly captures the combustion radicals, exerting a fire-retardant effect and preventing battery explosions (No. CN110215642A [83]). The flame retardant substances include trimethyl phosphate, triethyl phosphate, or tributyl phosphate. In 2020, GFI CO.LTD in the United States invented a fire extinguishing microcapsule with a core–shell structure. The shell of the microcapsule is composed of a compound or a mineral film (exfoliated montmorillonite) with a thickness ranging from 1 nanometer to 5 nanometers, filled with cross-linked gelatin, polyvinyl alcohol, urea, resorcinol–formaldehyde resin. The stability and emulsion of the microcapsule are achieved by using non-ionic or ionic surfactants as stabilizers or emulsifiers. This microcapsule exhibits long-term storage and safety properties at temperatures below room temperature and above the boiling point. The fire extinguishing agent rapidly expands in volume at a release temperature exceeding 70 °C, causing the shell to rupture and releasing externally (No. US20220152439A1 [84]). In 2021, a new type of LIBs microencapsulated fire extinguishing agent was prepared by mixing melamine-urea–formaldehyde resin prepolymer, gelatin solution, and montmorillonite suspension with fluorine-containing fire extinguishing materials by Shenzhen Electric Power Supply Bureau Co. The extinguishing agent has high wrapping strength and good stability, which meets the needs of long-term storage of LIBs extinguishing agent and can release fluorine-containing extinguishing materials to extinguish fire sources at high temperatures (No. CN113230577A [85]). Huazhong University of Science and Technology developed an efficient fire extinguishing agent with a core–shell structure, where melamine-urea–formaldehyde resin was used as the shell material and a mixture of perfluorohexane and heptafluorocyclopentane, acting as montmorillonite, defoaming agent, and fire extinguishing material, was used as the core material. By loading the prepared efficient fire extinguisher onto the outer surface of LIBs, effective safety protection is provided to ensure the fire safety of LIBs (No.CN113181589A, Fig. 29 [86]). The invention is capable of rupturing a highly efficient fire extinguishing agent when a LIBs experiences thermal runaway, thereby releasing fire suppression materials to promptly achieve both flame retardant and fire extinguishing effects. It ensures effective fire suppression while considering its cooling capacity, enabling rapid extinguishment and cooling of LIBs fires, effectively preventing battery reignition and ensuring user safety. The current working principles of microencapsulated fire extinguishing agents mainly consist of two approaches, namely, the high-temperature decomposition of the external shell material to release the core material, and the thermal expansion of the inner kernel material leading to the rupture of the outer shell and subsequent release. Considering the rapid temperature increase associated with thermal runaway phenomena, timely release of the core extinguishing agent is necessary to achieve the desired fire suppression concentration. The core material must not only rapidly breach the external casing but also be able to quickly disperse within the uncontrolled environment, thereby achieving effective fire suppression. The core firefighting agent component of microencapsulated fire extinguishants is primarily responsible for achieving effective fire suppression and cooling effects [84]. Due to the complex manufacturing process, the current composition of the core firefighting agent in microcapsules is single, which cannot simultaneously meet the diverse cooling requirements of different stages of battery thermal runaway ignition and propagation. Thus, there is still room for improvement in terms of performance. 3.5 Comparative analysis of different types of fire-extinguishing agent patents LIBs fires are different from conventional fires in that they contain a large amount of chemical energy inside the battery, the TR reaction continues spontaneously, and the fire is extremely prone to re-ignition [87]. The ideal LIBs extinguishing agent needs to be able to extinguish battery fires and cool the battery, but also needs to be able to absorb toxic gases such as HF and flammable and explosive gases such as H2 and CO. The action process of the extinguishing agent after the TR of the battery is divided into three stages: the cooling stage, the rapid temperature rise stage, and the slow temperature drop. During the cooling down phase, the extinguishing agent plays two main roles, namely phase change heat absorption and chemical barrier, which directly removes the heat generated by the battery through changes in the physical form of the extinguishing agent, while the chemical barrier indirectly reduces the heat generation by blocking the chemical reaction. During the rapid heat-up phase, the battery temperature rises rapidly from a very small value to a peak. As the extinguishing agent cannot completely stop the decomposition reaction inside the battery and the cooling effect of most extinguishing agents is poor, the battery temperature tends to rise almost vertically for different extinguishing agents after or even during the release of the extinguishing agent, with the battery temperature rising to a peak within a short period. The slow temperature drop phase generally takes a longer time [50]. The accumulation of heat will lead to further TR reactions, so controlling its temperature reduction is necessary to stop the TR and thermal spread of Li-ion batteries. Although most LIBs fire extinguishing agent patents have chosen liquid extinguishing agents as the primary area of research and development for rapid temperature reduction and the most effective extinguishing effect, there are still many unsolved safety issues remaining (Table 2 ). When the droplet size of the liquid extinguishing agent is in the right range, the droplets are sprayed through a fine water mist system carrying kinetic energy into the TR flame plume of the LIBs to extinguish the flame. The physical properties of the liquid extinguishing media, such as latent heat of evaporation, are then used to cool down the battery, thereby slowing down the internal chemical reaction of the battery. The liquid extinguishing agent is the most effective, but the sustained cooling capacity needs to be judged by the viscosity, surface tension, and rheological properties of the liquid extinguishing medium. Although the water-based extinguishing agent has a good cooling capacity, with the increase in the amount of extinguishing agent and spraying flow rate reduced, its cooling capacity significantly improved. But the sustained cooling capacity of water is poor, for Class A fires, only 5%–10% of the water used played a role in suppressing the fire [88]. Fine water mist has good electrical insulation, and many other advantages such as gas phase cooling mechanism, wet heat cooling combustion surfaces, dilution of oxygen, dilution of gaseous combustibles, impact on the flame, reduction of thermal radiation, and smoke removal [89], However, the spray strength, droplet concentration droplet volume will affect the fire-fighting performance of fine water mist, and the cooling effect is not enough, because the lithium battery TR will continue to release gas, so the suffocating effect of fine water mist is also weakened. In addition, strong adhesion in the battery surface of the fire extinguishing media sustained cooling capacity is stronger, and hydrogel fire extinguishing agent in the sustained cooling advantages has the ability to adsorb toxic gases. Therefore, using the temperature-sensitive type of hydrogel, it is more desirable to design a hydrogel fire extinguishing agent with different physical states at different temperatures, which can quickly extinguish the fire through latent heat of evaporation in liquid form before the characteristic temperature, and form a colloidal form after the characteristic temperature to effectively cool the LIBs and promptly absorb the toxic and harmful gases released during TR. The extinguishing mechanism of gas extinguishing agents is based on asphyxiation and interruption of a chain reaction through chemical inhibition, and the cooling ability is weak. As lithium battery fire is a deep fire, TR will release a large amount of gas, making it difficult for gaseous extinguishing agents to enter the interior of the battery, so in the suppression of lithium battery TR, gaseous extinguishing agents can effectively extinguish the flame, but cannot prevent the continuation of the TR reaction inside the lithium battery, which will easily lead to the re-ignition of the lithium battery (Table 2) [65]. Being a prevailing gas fire extinguishing agent for Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), perfluorocaprolactone possesses merits such as non-conductivity, exceptional cooling efficiency, and cleanliness. However, it exhibits a deficiency in sustained cooling capability and necessitates specific conditions in the fire extinguishing enclosure. Heptafluoropropane and perfluorohexanone have proven effective in extinguishing fires, yet violent chain decomposition reactions still occur within the LIBs. Hence, it is advisable to cease extinguishing agent spraying only after addressing the susceptibility to re-ignition. When approaching fire extinguishing, early application and sustained spraying are recommended to thwart re-ignition. Nevertheless, the carbon dioxide full flooding method at 15 MPa does not prove efficacious in fire extinguishment. [90]. HFC-227 extinguishing agent is effective in fighting lithium battery fires [91]. As gaseous fire extinguishing agent related patents are perflourohexanone with liquid, a solid combination of fire extinguishing agents, it should be noted that even so, perflourohexanone high temperature will also decompose toxic gases, and the workflow of the composite fire extinguishing agent is more complex, which will make perflourohexanone composite fire extinguishing agent face another challenge. Using water-based extinguishing agents as the baseline, a comparative analysis was conducted across ten different fire suppressants in terms of their performance across five dimensions: fire extinguishment, rapid cooling, sustained cooling, gas absorption, and low conductivity (Fig. 30 ). The extinguishing mechanism of solid extinguishing agents is based on chemical inhibition [92], but the cooling capacity is generally poor [50,80]. Among them, a dry powder extinguishing agent can initially extinguish the open fire, but cannot stop re-ignition; an aerosol extinguishing agent can stop the spread of heat at the initial stage of TR, but experimental research is scarce (Table 2). Therefore, the LIBs solid fire extinguishing agent invention patent is not suitable for use as the only fire extinguishing medium for LIBs TR accidents. Although the solid extinguishing agent can quickly cool down and use portable fire extinguishers, which are easy to use, the continuous cooling ability is poor and has a large impact on the visibility of the scene, which will affect the smooth development of rescue and escape at the scene. The current invention patent of lithium battery fire extinguishing agent mainly focuses on solving the issue of thermal runaway in electric vehicle power batteries, with less involvement in the fire safety of large-scale energy storage power stations. Further efforts are required to broaden the scope of accident scenarios, analyze the similarities and differences between battery accidents in energy storage power stations and electric vehicle batteries, and develop effective fire extinguishing agents and fire suppression systems for other battery safety scenarios such as energy storage power stations. 4 Analysis of patented surfactants for LIBs extinguishing agents At room temperature, water has a specific heat capacity of approximately 4.2 × 103 J kg−1 K−1 and can absorb a significant amount of heat during vaporization. However, when water mist encounters a surface with extremely high temperature, such as the surface of an overheated battery or a solid object, a thin layer of vapor forms between the solid surface and the water, known as the Leidenfrost effect. This vapor layer prevents direct contact between water and the solid surface, inhibiting heat absorption. Instead, the heat dissipates only through thin-film boiling, significantly reducing the cooling capacity of the water [93]. Surfactants are compounds with a high capacity and efficiency to significantly reduce surface and interfacial tension, and they are active at the surface and interface. They are essential components in patents for specialized lithium-ion battery fire extinguishers. The molecular structure of surfactants can be divided into two asymmetric parts: one part is a hydrophilic polar group, and the other part is a hydrophobic non-polar group [94]. Among them, the hydrophilic polar groups can form strong electrostatic attractions or hydrogen bonds with water molecules, causing the hydrophilic groups to disperse in the aqueous phase, while the hydrophobic groups tend to move away from water. Surfactants also have the ability to solubilize non-water-soluble organic substances [95–97]. By introducing different types of surfactants into water, the physical properties of water, such as surface tension and particle size, can be altered. This leads to a reduction in the Leidenfrost effect and enhances the heat transfer capability of water, thereby improving its cooling efficiency. Additionally, surfactants aid in the dissolution of other additives that are originally insoluble in water but contribute to firefighting and cooling effects. This results in the formation of a homogeneous and stable extinguishing agent. Consequently, surfactants play a crucial role in the formulation of firefighting agents. Surfactants can be classified into two main categories, ionic surfactant (IS) and nonionic surfactant (NS), based on their ionization in water [98–100]. Ionic surfactants can be classified as cationic, anionic, and, in turn, amphoteric based on the charge on the polar head group (Fig. 31 ) [101]. As the main types of surfactants used in the content of the patent are nonionic and anionic surfactants, only the two aforementioned surfactants are analyzed. Three different types of surfactants, anionic surfactant sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), cationic surfactant cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), and nonionic surfactant polyoxyethylene (20) dehydrated sorbitan monolaurate (Tween 20), were added to water to perform cooling experiments on hot plates (Fig. 32 ) [102]. It was found that surface tension and contact angle decreased with increasing surfactant concentration, which resulted in the better spreading of the surfactant on the test plates and thus evaporation at a faster rate. However, the TR process of a battery is different from that of a hot steel plate in that not only is there material ejected from the inside of the battery and accompanied by flames, but if the surface tension is too low the extinguishing agent will not reach the surface of the battery. Therefore, for LIBs fires, the surface tension of the extinguishing agent needs to be regulated within a suitable range [103]. Analysis of the LIBs fire extinguishing agent patents reveals that surfactants are used in the formulations of 11 of the 20 patents, mainly liquid fire agents. Fluorocarbon and hydrocarbon surfactants are more frequently used, nonionic surfactants and anionic surfactants are four respectively, and there are three other patents where the specific type of surfactant cannot be determined through the patent content (Table 3 ). 4.1 Nonionic surfactants Nonionic surfactants do not dissociate when dissolved in water and the hydrophilic groups in their molecules are approximately the same as the lipophilic groups of ionic surfactants, which are mainly composed of oxygen-containing groups (such as hydroxyl groups and polyoxyethylene chains) with a certain number. As the nonionic surfactant does not exist in solution in an ionic state, it is highly stable, not easily affected by the presence of strong electrolytes or by acids and bases, can be mixed with other types of surfactants, has good compatibility, has good solubility in various solvents and does not strongly adsorb on solid surfaces. Nonionic surfactants are classified by hydrophilic groups, including polyoxyethylene, esters, and nitrogen-containing [104]. 4.1.1 Polyoxyethylene ether-based nonionic surfactants (1) Polyoxyethylene glycol (AEO) Polyoxyethylene ether is a condensation of aliphatic alcohols with ethylene oxide and is a lipophilic emulsifier that enhances the solubility of certain substances in organic solvents. The low foaming and high dispersibility of polyoxyethylene ether make it particularly active in the dispersion and emulsification of suspensions and emulsions. The molarity of the ethylene oxide addition during the synthesis of polyoxyethylene ethers determines their hydrophilic or lipophilic solubility properties. Polyoxyethylene ethers can usually be completely soluble from oil to water. An obvious disadvantage of polyoxyethylene ethers is that they decompose at around 300 °C [105], which makes them very viscous in aqueous solutions and prone to gelation, a situation that can be resolved by the addition of alcohols such as sorbitol [106]. In addition, AEO has low foaming power and poor foam stability [107] and is not suitable for use in foam fire extinguishing agents but low foaminess is more conducive to heat transfer in fine water sprays [73]. The surfactant used in patent CN111840879A, patent CN115400384A, and patent CN115671640A is polyoxyethylene ether (AEO) of primary alcohol. Two of the patents CN115400384A and CN115671640A, invented by the Beijing University of Technology, take into account the issue of thermal stability in their formulations and both incorporate polyols. (2) Seconal polyoxyethylene ether (SEO) Sec-alcohol polyoxyethylene ethers are characterized by easy flow, low viscosity, and good permeability. The most significant advantage over other types of alcohol ethers is that they have better flow properties even at low temperatures. In terms of environmental criteria, SEO is more environmentally friendly than AEO polyols because it is more biodegradable and therefore more suitable for environmental requirements and much less harmful to humans. One of the drawbacks of sec-ol polyoxyethylene ethers is that the emulsification and cleaning function of sec-ol polyoxyethylene ethers is reduced due to the high number of unreacted sec-ol in the finished product [108]. (3) Alkyl phenol ethoxylates (APEO) Alkylphenol ethoxylates are an important class of nonionic surfactants with good anti-electrolyte stability and good miscibility with other surfactants and are commonly used as nonionic surfactants in emulsion polymerization [109]. In the chemical building materials industry, alkylphenol ethoxylates are mainly used as emulsifiers for polymer compounds or synthetic resin emulsions, and as stabilizers for synthetic latexes. APEO is used as a wetting agent, dispersant, and foam inhibitor for pigments and fillers, etc. APEO has low foaming power and poor foam stability, but because of its excellent wetting properties, it can be used as a wetting agent for foam fire extinguishing agents [107]. In the study of fine water mist fire extinguishing agents with APEO and triethanolamine emulsification of fluorosurfactants and sodium lactate, dimethylformamide (DMF) additives improve the fire extinguishing performance to play an auxiliary role. Experiments show that at certain concentrations, the presence of APEO and triethanolamine can shorten the fire extinguishing time and improve the fire extinguishing performance, and if the concentration increases the fire extinguishing time remains the same [110]. Using APEO as a fine water mist additive, the fire extinguishing performance of nonionic liquid fine water mist and pure water fine water mist at different mass fractions were compared in terms of maximum fire zone temperature, high-temperature duration, temperature reduction rate, and CO content in the smoke, etc. It was found that the broken ether bond had a lower HLB value due to high-temperature action, and the broken ether bond and hydrogen ions were also able to capture the free radicals of the chain reaction and weaken the chain reaction [111]. However, based on AEPO, biodegradation is difficult, and harmful by-products are generated during the production process. The constituent substance of APEO, NEPO, is highly toxic to mammals and aquatic organisms. NP, OP, NPEO, and OPEO are all classified as environmental endocrine disruptors. The European Union banned this substance in 2003, and currently, APEO is being gradually replaced by AEO. 4.1.2 Ester-based nonionic surfactants (1) Glycerides Glycerol esters are substances produced by the esterification of glycerol and fatty acids. The fatty acids in the raw material are divided into fatty acids and unsaturated fatty acids. Depending on the fatty acids of the reactants, the resulting glycerol esters can be divided into C3H5(OH)(OCOR), C3H5(OH)(OCOR)2, and C3H5(OCOR)3, glycerol mono-acid, glycerol acid ester, and glycerol triglyceride. Glyceryl monoacids are very poorly soluble and are essentially insoluble in water. Glyceryl triglycerides, which contain a higher number of carbon, have a relatively wide range of uses [112]. Yang et al. [113] used glyceryl monostearate as an anti-flocculant to prepare a new type of gaseous cold aerosol efficient fire extinguishing agent, which better reduced the particle size of the powder and improved the fire extinguishing effect. (2) Sorbitol esters Sorbitol esters are generally referred to as sorbitol fatty acid esters with water loss, also known as Span-type nonionic surfactants, and are important emulsifiers. Span-type emulsifiers are harmless to the body, but require organic co-solvents to dissolve better in water. 3% concentration of Span20 has a higher cooling rate than the same concentration of Span40 for extinguishing cooking oil fires [114]. Tween, derived from the combination of Span and ethylene oxide, incorporates additional hydrophilic polyoxyethylene groups within its molecular structure. This hydrophilic nature renders it suitable for serving as an emulsifier in oil-in-water (O/W) type emulsions. When coupled with other emulsifiers like sodium lauryl sulfate or Span class, it enhances emulsion stability by fostering synergistic effects. The sorbitol ester t added in the fine water spray on the oil pool fire suppression, f found that when the fire “water-in-oil” effect can make the oil scattered in the water phase, water molecules wrapped around the oil molecules, thus weakening the oil burning [115]. Three nonionic surfactants with different surface tensions, Capstone™ FS-51, Tween 20, and 1-heptanol, were added to a fine aqueous mist and used in a LIBs fire extinguishing temperature reduction experiment. In the single additive tests, the cooling effects were in descending order of Tween 20, 1-heptanol, pure water, and FS-51 (Fig. 33 ) [116]. 4.1.3 Nitrogen-containing nonionic surfactants (1) Alkyl alcohol amides The alkyl alcohol amide series is actively developed as a widely used nonionic surfactant. Alkyl alcohol amides have no cloud point and their good foaming and foam stability make them often used as foam enhancers and foam stabilizers in a wide range of industries [117]. The perfluoroalkyl ether surfactants used in patent CN109091790A are obtained by reacting perfluoroalkyl acyl fluoride and fluorinated metal salts as raw materials with halogenated alkane substrates under a halogenated metal catalyst to obtain the target product, perfluoroalkyl ether compounds [118]. As a fluorocarbon nonionic surfactant, it has high surface activity, strong foaming properties [119], is easily soluble in water, chemically stable, and resistant to acids, alkalis, and high temperatures, but perfluoroalkyl ethers are seriously contaminating, cause oxidative stress in the liver [120], and have significant toxicogenic effects [121]. (2) Block polyether-based nonionic surfactants Block polyether-type active agents are copolymers (block polymers) produced by the copolymerization of ethylene oxide (EO) and propylene oxide (PO), in which the polyoxypropylene group formed by EO acts as a lipophilic group and the polyoxyethylene formed by PO acts as a hydrophilic group, and are an emerging class of non-ionic surfactants [122]. The hydrophilic and lipophilic properties of the products are controlled by adjusting the ratio of polyoxypropylene to polyoxyethylene. According to the polymerisation method, they can be divided into whole-embedded and hetero-embedded types. The whole-embedded type consists of a regular arrangement of polyoxypropylene groups and polyoxyethylene groups, the structure of which can be simplified as ABA type [123], while the hetero-embedded type introduces a random copolymerisation chain of ethylene oxide and propylene oxide into the molecular chain, thus enhancing the performance. The whole-embedded polyethers are the most abundant and widely used, of which the whole-embedded type is the most abundant and widely used, and the general formula for both is Fig. 34 [124]. In addition, patent CN111840879A uses a non-ionic polymeric fluorinated surfactant (FC-4430, FC-4432); the exact composition of the fluorinated surfactant cannot be known in detail due to patent protection. What can be established is that the surfactants are soluble and compatible with most polymers, can be dispersed in water in any proportion, are not easily affected by the presence of electrolytes and certain inorganic salts, are not significantly affected by changes in pH (Table 4 ) [125], continue to act during drying and curing, and retain surface activity in the organic phase of the polymer system, which, due to the absence in the structure of PFOS group or PFOA group in the structure, and only four carbon atoms are used, so it does not involve environmental pollution or difficult degradation.
