However, the patent invention is a fine water mist extinguishing agent, FC-4430 and FC-4432 have stronger foaming properties and are more suitable as foam extinguishing agents, as fine water mist extinguishing agents, the stronger foaming properties will affect the cooling effect of the extinguishing agent [116]. 4.2 Anionic surfactants Anionic surfactants adsorb to the surface of particles to give them a negative charge, stabilizing the dispersion through electrostatic repulsion and spatial resistance. The main anionic surfactants are sulphonate surfactants, carboxylate surfactants, phosphate surfactants, and sulfate surfactants [104]. 4.2.1 Carboxylate surfactants Carboxylate surfactants have long carbon chains, many active adsorption sites, and branched chains that are spatially repulsive and have excellent dispersion properties for suspension systems due to their special structure. Compared to conventional surfactants, polycarboxylate surfactants have the following characteristics: they are less sensitive to ions, pH, and temperature in suspension systems, have high dispersion stability, and are less prone to settling and flocculation. Polycarboxylate surfactants can increase the content of the dispersed phase, significantly reduce the viscosity of the dispersed system, and have better flowability at high solids content, reducing raw material costs and equipment wear. A wide range of raw materials can be selected, and different types of copolymer monomers can be chosen. The designability of molecular structure and properties makes it easy to form a series of products. Fatty carboxylates have strong foaming properties and stable foam, but they are irritating to the skin and eyes and have poor emulsification ability for oils, so they are often used in combination with other types of surfactants. Carboxylate fluorocarbon surfactants are thermally stable, but have low solubility when combined with cationic hydrocarbons. Both patent US20140034864A1 and patent JP2017528866A use carboxylate surfactants, with patent JP2017528866A using a perfluoropolyether carboxylic acid-based surfactant that is toxic and decomposes above 350 °C [126], while the TR flame temperature of LIBs can reach around 600 °C [127]. 4.2.2 Phosphate salts surfactants Phosphate ester serves as the representative of phosphorus-containing surfactants that have the advantages of low toxicity, low irritation, good biodegradability, good compatibility, good water solubility, good stability, and low surface tension. The phosphate ester salt type fluorocarbon surfactant patent CN113209536A is applied to phosphate ester surfactants, which are non-foaming and often used as defoamers, and are more suitable for fine water mist type fire extinguishing agents. 4.2.3 Sulfonate surfactants Sulfonate surfactants mainly include formaldehyde condensates of naphthalene sulfonate, formaldehyde condensates of alkyl naphthalene sulfonate, lignin sulfonate surfactants, and amino sulfonate surfactants. They are stable in acidic or alkaline media and do not combine with calcium and magnesium ions in the system to form precipitates and have strong resistance to hard water. Sulphonate surfactants can be easily used in combination with other surfactants and are widely used. The addition of sodium dodecylbenzene sulfonate (SDBS) to the Li-ion battery TR suppression system enhances the cooling effect by changing the physical properties of the fine water mist droplets, inhibits the chain reaction by generating ions, and reduces the flame temperature by absorbing heat through thermal decomposition [128]. The three main fluorocarbon surfactants of the sulfonate type are perfluorinated alkyl sulfonic acid (salt), perfluoropropyl alkyl sulfonate, and perfluorinated alkoxybenzene sulfonate, which is highly resistant to oxidation, have long storage time for application in fire extinguishing agents, have low electrolyte sensitivity, and are highly foamable [129]. Patent CN115192952A uses perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) with good oleophobicity, hydrophobicity, foaming and heat resistance, stability, and extreme permanence makes it suitable for high-temperature environments and operations in contact with strong acids and bases, is widely used as an active agent, dispersant for the production of detergents, coatings, binders, foam extinguishing agents, etc. The use of PFOS in foam extinguishing agents can be traced back to 1949 when 3 M added PFOS as a surfactant to foam extinguishing agents. However, recent studies have shown that PFOS is one of the most difficult organic pollutants to degrade in the world and was banned by the US Environmental Protection Agency in 2000. 4.3 Comparative analysis of different surfactants The selection of surfactants in LIBs fire extinguishing agents requires comprehensive consideration of surface activity, thermal stability, foaming, environmental protection, electrical conductivity, and other properties (Table 5 ). At present, the surfactants used in LIBs fire extinguishing agent patents are mainly hydrocarbon and fluorocarbon anionic and non-ionic surfactants, with fewer and more concentrated types. AEO hydrocarbon non-ionic surfactants, which are used more often, have strong emulsification and surface activity but will decompose at high temperatures, thus affecting the fire extinguishing effect, and alcohols need to be added to overcome the problem of high-temperature decomposition. Although the fluorocarbon surfactants have the advantages of high surface activity, high heat resistance, and high chemical stability, the patents only FC-4430 and FC-4432 compound environmental protection requirements, perfluorooctane sulfonate, perfluoropolyether carboxylate, perfluorinated alkyl ether substances are toxic and difficult to degrade. In the selection process of surfactants also need to consider the different types of use of fire extinguishing agents, including phosphate ester as an antifoaming agent, no foaming, AEO foaming is also low, the above two types of substances in terms of foaming are the preferred choice of fine water mist fire extinguishing agent, while perfluoroalkyl ether, carboxylate, sulfonate, FC-4430 foaming are stronger, can be used as a foam fire extinguishing agent of choice, if applied to a fine water mist extinguishing agent, it will affect the fire extinguishing effect. In addition, the system of surfactants currently used in fire extinguishing agent patents is relatively single and the types are relatively concentrated. Leveraging the robust electrostatic attraction existing between anionic and cationic head groups, this mechanism facilitates the establishment of a connection between two surfactant molecules bearing opposite charges. This diminishes the repulsion among ionic head groups that carry the same charge within a single cationic or anionic surfactant molecule. Consequently, this process encourages the seamless formation of micelles and leads to a more compact arrangement of molecules at the gas–liquid interface. [130]. The use of anionic fluorinated surfactants in combination with cationic hydrocarbon surfactants is an important research direction worth exploring. The surface tension of the ternary compounding system consisting of anionic, cationic, and non-ionic surfactants is significantly lower than that of the binary compounding system, and the foam force and foam stability are better than those of the binary compounding system. Therefore, for the study of foam extinguishing agents for LIBs, ternary compounding system surfactants can also be tried [131]. 5 Summary and outlook LIBs, as a crucial energy conversion medium in various real-life scenarios such as energy storage and power propulsion, face significant safety challenges that serve as a crucial bottleneck for their widespread societal adoption. This issue has garnered widespread attention across various industries and sectors. Many scholars have attempted to stabilize the thermal runaway phenomenon of LIBs by altering the internal composition of the materials. However, this inevitably affects the energy density of LIBs. Moreover, the thermal runaway phenomenon in LIBs mostly occurs only under abusive conditions. Therefore, reducing the overall energy density of LIBs would be sacrificing the core for the sake of the periphery. Instead, a more appropriate approach would be to tailor effective fire extinguishing agents specifically for LIBs, allowing for timely intervention when a thermal runaway incident arises. This proactive intervention is the ideal solution to address safety concerns related to LIBs. The present study conducts an analysis of LIBs patents in China, the United States, Europe, Japan, and South Korea. The findings reveal that Japan leads the world in LIBs patent inventions. The United States exhibits the most frequent flow of patents with other regions. Although China lags behind in LIBs patent inventions, it stands out in terms of patent inventions related to LIBs fire extinguishing agents. In the 451,760 patents related to lithium-ion batteries, there are only 20 patents that truly involve the development of lithium-ion battery fire extinguishing agents. The earliest patent for a lithium-ion battery fire extinguishing agent was filed in the United States in 2012, while China holds the highest number of patents for lithium-ion battery fire extinguishing agents, with a total of 14 patents. The liquid fire extinguishers with prominent cooling abilities (including water-based, water gel, foam-based extinguishers, etc.) hold the highest number of invention patents (totaling 10 patents). However, they still struggle to effectively address persistent cooling, gas absorption, and thermal propagation issues associated with thermal runaway batteries. On the other hand, gas and solid lithium battery extinguishers achieve rapid fire suppression through chemical inhibition, but their cooling capacity remains insufficient to tackle battery reignition problems. The number of patents related to microencapsulated lithium battery fire extinguishers is also quite substantial, totaling four. This method involves enclosing effective fire extinguishing agents within small-sized shells. On one hand, this increases the specific surface area of the extinguishing substance, thereby enhancing its fire suppression and cooling effects. On the other hand, the encapsulation within the shells creates a new stable form that overcomes the physical limitations of the original substance. This represents a significant approach in the research of fire extinguishers for lithium-ion batteries. Due to the thermal runaway incidents in lithium-ion batteries being profound fire hazards, the extinguishing agents must not only rapidly suppress the open flames but also possess strong and sustained cooling capabilities to fundamentally mitigate the exothermic reactions and gas release within the lithium-ion battery, thereby preventing re-ignition. Moreover, the extinguishing agents should also possess the ability to absorb toxic and flammable gases released during the thermal runaway process, thereby reducing the likelihood of poisoning and explosion accidents at the fire scene. In the future, the application of lithium-ion batteries will undoubtedly continue to evolve towards higher energy densities. Simultaneously, the role of lithium-ion battery thermal runaway extinguishers as crucial passive safety measures will become increasingly significant. A comprehensive analysis of the characteristics of lithium-ion battery thermal runaway, the extinguishing advantages of various types of extinguishers, the principles of extinguishment, and cooling properties indicates that temperature-sensitive hydrogel extinguishers represent a crucial developmental direction for future lithium-ion battery extinguishing agents (Fig. 35 ). In the early stages of thermal runaway in lithium-ion batteries, they can release in a liquid state. By utilizing the latent heat of water evaporation, an open flame can be extinguished, rapidly cooling the surface of the lithium-ion battery. As the surface temperature of the battery increases, the temperature-sensitive property of the water colloid comes into play, gradually transforming the liquid into a colloid, providing sustained cooling to the battery. This process slows down the deep-seated chemical reactions within the battery and effectively controls the spread of heat between individual cells. By incorporating materials such as calcium salts, the water colloid can absorb toxic gases like HF generated during the thermal runaway process and further enhance its capacity to absorb small molecule flammable and explosive gases. Surfactants are an essential component of the extinguishing agent formula for lithium-ion batteries. In the patents for the invention of the extinguishing agent, both hydrocarbon and fluorocarbon non-ionic and anionic surfactants are used. Hydrocarbon non-ionic surfactants have relatively weaker foaming capabilities, making them more suitable for water-based extinguishing agents. Among these, fatty alcohol polyoxyethylene ethers are utilized in three patents. This substance exhibits high dispersibility and does not foam, making it particularly effective in dispersing suspensions and emulsions. To further enhance thermal stability, the addition of alcohol-based co-surfactants is required. Fluorocarbon surfactants are generally characterized by strong foaming properties, making them more suitable for foam fire extinguishing agents. Among the numerous fluorocarbon surfactants used in patents, only FC-4430 complies with environmental standards; the remaining components have been banned by relevant environmental protection authorities due to their poor biodegradability and high toxicity [132]. But the relevant patents are still in force. In the future, the application of surfactants as fire extinguishing agents in the field of lithium-ion batteries can be explored through the use of multiple surfactant compounds. Jianqi Zhang is a serving member of the Inner Mongolia Fire and Rescue Service. She is currently pursuing a doctor's degree in safety science and engineering at the State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology, China. Her research interests mainly focus on the safety of lithium-ion batteries, especially on the LIBs fire extinguishing agent. Tao Fan received his Ph.D. degree in safety science and engineering at the State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology, China. He is currently engaged in scientific research at the Industrial Safety Research Institute of the China Academy of Work Safety Sciences. His research interests mainly focus on the safety of clean energy (such as fire prevention of lithium ionbatteries, lithium-ion batteries fire extinguishing agents). Shuai Yuan received his M.S. degree (2018) in Safety Science and Engineering from Northeast petroleum University, China. He is currently pursuing a Ph.D. degree in safety science and engineering at the State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology, China. His research interests mainly focus on the safety of lithium-ion batteries (such as fire prevention of lithium ion batteries). Chongye Chang received her master’s degree (2020) in Safety Science and Engineering from Nanjing University of Science and Technology, China. She is currently pursuing a Ph.D. degree in safety science and engineering at the State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology, China. Her research work mainly focuses on thermal runaway of Li-ion battery. Kuo Wang obtained his master degree at Nanjing Tech University, and is currently pursuing his Ph.D. at the State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology. His research interests focus on lithium-ion battery safety evaluation, fire suppression, and high-voltage electrolyte. Ziwei Song obtained his master’s degree from the China People’s Armed Police Force Academy in 2019. Currently, he works at the China People’s Police University, focusing on research related to the thermal runaway mechanism and safety management of lithium-ion batteries. Xinming Qian received his Ph.D. in safety engineering from North Eastern University, China, 1996. He is now a professor at safety engineering at State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and Technology Beijing Institute of Technology. His research has focused on the safety of hazardous chemical substance, such as Lithium-ion battery.

coredata.dc:description: While newer, more efficient Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and extinguishing agents have been developed to reduce the occurrence of thermal runaway accidents, there is still a scarcity of research focused on the application of surfactants in different LIBs extinguishing agents, particularly in terms of patented technologies. The aim of this review paper is to provide an overview of the technological progress of LIBs and LIBs extinguishing agents in terms of patents in Korea, Japan, Europe, the United States, China, etc. The initial part of this review paper is sort out LIBs technology development in different regions. In addition, to compare LIBs extinguishing agent progress and challenges of liquid, solid, combination of multiple, and microencapsulated. The subsequent sectionof this review focuses on an in-depth analysis dedicated to the efficiency and challenges faced by the surfactants corresponding design principles of LIBs extinguishing agents, such as nonionic and anionic surfactants. A total of 451,760 LIBs-related patent and 20 LIBs-fire-extinguishing agent-related patent were included in the analyses. The extinguishing effect, cooling performance, and anti-recombustion on different agents have been highlighted. After a comprehensive comparison of these agents, this review suggests that temperature-sensitive hydrogel extinguishing agent is ideal for the effective control of LIBs fire. The progress and challenges of surfactants have been extensively examined, focusing on key factors such as surface activity, thermal stability, foaming properties, environmental friendliness, and electrical conductivity. Moreover, it is crucial to emphasize that the selection of a suitable surfactant must align with the extinguishing strategy of the extinguishing agent for optimal firefighting effectiveness.
